definition: wording/way of expressing something/turn of phrase/diction
to handle/to manage/to put in order/to arrange/to administer/to execute/to take action on/to plan
word/statement/speech/lyrics/CL:組|组[zu3],個|个[ge4]/a form of lyric poetry, flourishing in the Song dynasty 宋朝|宋朝[Song4 chao2]/CL:首[shou3]

sentences.english: The wording on the left ensures that full "evening dress" is worn by everyone.
sentences.chinese: 左側的措詞確保到會者一律穿上全套“晚軍服”。

sentences.english: We disagreed over the wording of the agreement .
sentences.chinese: 我們對協議的措詞有不同意見。

sentences.english: We should reconsider it and weight the wording.
sentences.chinese: 我們應該對此條重新考慮，推敲一下措詞。

sentences.english: His speech at the meeting was strongly worded.
sentences.chinese: 他在會上的講話，措詞強硬。

sentences.english: You'd better recast the first paragraph in more formal wording.
sentences.chinese: 你最好用更正式的措詞把第一段重寫一下。

sentences.english: The novel does contain some awkward phrasing.
sentences.chinese: 小說裏也出現了一些彆扭的措詞。

sentences.english: Note the use of the word replace.
sentences.chinese: 請注意“替換”這個措詞的含義。

sentences.english: An appeal so worded could not be set aside without a grave responsibility .
sentences.chinese: 這呼籲如此措詞，使我感到責任重大，不易置之不理。

sentences.english: Partly the problem with globalization has always been that the term, culturally speaking, is so vague.
sentences.chinese: 全球化的部分問題從文化角度上講是一個模糊的措詞。

sentences.english: The boy had two short awkward letters from Ben.
sentences.chinese: 這孩子來過兩封措詞生硬的短信。

sentences.english: Parents often phrase this question more colorfully.
sentences.chinese: 父母們的措詞通常更加豐富多彩。

sentences.english: The wording is likely to lead to ambiguity.
sentences.chinese: 這種措詞可能會引出歧義。

sentences.english: Translucency might be a better term.
sentences.chinese: 半透明或許是更合適的措詞。

sentences.english: There are signs of youth and in experience in his wordage.
sentences.chinese: 在他的措詞中表現出年輕和無經驗的跡象。

definition: to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
hard to tell if it's real or sham
important matter that must be kept secret (idiom); don't breathe a word of it to anyone!
each sticks to his own version (idiom); a dialogue of the deaf
to interpret (a visual document, a medical exam, an historical event etc)/to analyze data (from a chip, a black box etc)
lit. draw legs on a snake (idiom); fig. to ruin the effect by adding sth superfluous/to overdo it
to turn a deaf ear to (idiom); to pretend not to hear
(coll.) to tamper with/to mess around with
